Updated November     pm



In three days Katie Stultz had to get as many people from the UW campus registered to vote as possible PERIOD

Stultz the ASUW legislative programming coordinator worked over the summer to direct a campaign oversee volunteers and organize plans all in the effort to get students to vote PERIOD

Since the university runs on the quarter system and classes start in late September there have only been three days to execute the campaign PERIOD So far  voter registration forms have been sent out to residence halls Greek houses and the campus community PERIOD

 Stultz said PERIOD 

ASUW is one of several student organizations involved in UW Votes a campuswide effort to raise awareness about and increase access to voter registration PERIOD Other organizations involved include WASHPirg RHSA Interfraternity Council Panhellenic Young Democrats and College Republicans PERIOD

Sarah Round the ASUW director of operations and liaison to the ASUWs Office of Government Relations said she was dismayed when she read that the average voter is  years old PERIOD One reason ASUW has taken a stronger position in voter registration is its importance in making sure student voices are heard by the Legislature Round said PERIOD

 Round said PERIOD 

Stultz along with other ASUW coordinators is now in the process of waiting for the registration forms to be collected from drop boxes and pickup spots around campus PERIOD

Stultz noted that a common response regarding the upcoming election has been that students dont take interim elections seriously PERIOD

 Stultz said PERIOD 

In the  Legislative session the UWs state funding was cut by . million as a result of the  state supplemental budget PERIOD The Legislature will set the  biennial budget in the upcoming  legislative session and the UW is preparing for more cuts to the universitys state appropriations in the new budget PERIOD

In  the nonprofit organization Rock the Vote held a nationwide poll among young voters and found that  percent of  to 29yearold adults are registered voters but when it comes to the upcoming election in November only  percent have been paying  of attention and  percent are not likely to vote in it PERIOD

In the same poll education and the cost of college is second only to jobs and the economy for what young voters are most concerned about and  percent are worried about not having enough money to pay for school or student loans PERIOD

 Round said PERIOD 

Stultz said that having only three days of school so far to execute the plan to get students registered has been a challenge to the campaign PERIOD

 she said PERIOD

On Tuesday Stultz will move into the process of educating people to vote and getting ready for a forum on the initiatives on the ballot PERIOD

Ben Henry Graduate and Professional Student Senate GPSS vice president said that GPSS will be collaborating with ASUW on the forum PERIOD ASUW and GPSS will invite representatives from campaigns to come to discuss election measures PERIOD

 Henry said PERIOD

Stultz said that October will be dedicated to getting students to vote in the upcoming election and ensuring that voters understand the importance of becoming educated about the initiatives on the ballot PERIOD

 Stultz said 

Reach reporter Katie Burke at newsdailyuw.com PERIOD

A recent investigation led by New York Attorney General Andrew Cuomo found that a  determine eligibility for private loans based in large part on the colleges students attend rather than individuals credit worthiness PERIOD

Prior to this finding New York passed the Student Lending Accountability Transparency and Enforcement SLATE Act of  to protect collegebound students from aggressive loan industry practices PERIOD Cuomo also drafted a code of conduct for student loan schools and organizations to abide by PERIOD

 The student loan industry makes  billion per year PERIOD

 Private lenders currently control  of the student loan market and continue to grow PERIOD

Find out about student loans rights the Code of Conduct and settlements at this link PERIOD

ASUW student lobbyist Bryce McKibben said the Washington state legislature has not followed New York by drafting legislation on student loans as a result of a lack of evidence and timeliness since discussion came up toward the end of the legislative session PERIOD He added that he did not know about different rates being offered to students based on the colleges they attend PERIOD

The Sunshine Act a bill that seeks to fulfill purposes similar to those of the New York bill was sponsored by senators Edward M PERIOD Kennedy DMass. and Richard J PERIOD Durbin DIll. pERIOD On June  attorneys general from  states including Washington sent a letter to U.S PERIOD Senators requesting that they pass the Student Loan Sunshine Act PERIOD

Kay Lewis director of UW Student Financial Aid said her office was aware that rates on private loans are set based on a variety of factors PERIOD

 she said PERIOD

The practice of offering different rates based on which school a student attends does not break any laws PERIOD

In a recent publication Cuomo said lenders divide colleges into groups based on how their alumni repay federally subsidized loans PERIOD Depending on the default rate at their school students are eligible for different private loan rates PERIOD Within those ranges the focus is on a students credit record PERIOD

Some schools have  and investigations have discovered that some lenders pay to get on those lists PERIOD

 Lewis said PERIOD 

McKibben said he contacted the Attorney Generals office about pursuing an investigation in Washington but they have not gotten back to him yet PERIOD

Kristin Alexander media relations manager for Washington Attorney General Rob McKenna said 

As of this week according to a press release from Cuomos office  Twentysix schools have also agreed to the code PERIOD
